statement:
Recall that, for $k\geq 0$, the Bernoulli numbers $B_k$ are defined as
the coefficients in the Taylor expansion: $$\begin{aligned}
\label{ber} \frac{t}{e^t-1}=\sum_{k\geq 0} B_k \frac{t^k}{k!}.\end{aligned}$$
Just to name a few:
$$B_0=1,\quad B_1=-\frac{1}{2},\quad B_2=\frac{1}{6},\quad B_3=0,\quad B_4=-\frac{1}{30},\ B_5=0,\ldots,\ B_{10}=\frac{5}{66},\ldots$$

If $k\geq 3$ is odd then $B_k=0$.

From the right hand side of (\[ber\]) we extract the term corresponding
to $k=1$: $$\begin{aligned}
\label{ber2} \frac{t}{e^t-1}=-\frac{t}{2}+\sum_{k\geq 0,\ k\neq 1} B_k \frac{t^k}{k!}.\end{aligned}$$
Thus: $$\begin{aligned}
\label{ber21} \frac{t}{e^t-1}+\frac{t}{2}=\sum_{k\geq 0,\ k\neq 1} B_k \frac{t^k}{k!}\end{aligned}$$
and the left hand side can be rewritten as: $$\begin{aligned}
\label{ber3} \frac{t}{e^t-1}+\frac{t}{2}= \frac{2t+t(e^t-1)}{2(e^t-1)} =
\frac{t}{2}\cdot \frac{e^t+1}{e^t-1}=\frac{t}{2} \cdot \frac{e^{t/2}+e^{-t/2}}{e^{t/2}-e^{-t/2}}.\end{aligned}$$
Hence, if one replaces $t$ by $-t$ then (\[ber3\]) is unchanged. Since
(\[ber3\]) is the left hand side of (\[ber21\]), the quantity
$$\sum_{k\geq 0,\ k\neq 1} B_k \frac{t^k}{k!}$$ is also unchanged when
$t$ is exchanged by $-t$, and so we must have $B_k=(-1)^kB_k$ for
$k\neq 1$. We conclude that if $k\geq 3$ and $k$ is odd, $B_k=0$.
names: the odd Bernoulli numbers are zero
